Since when was the average size a niche on social media?

31/07/2022

Zara Osako reflects on the importance of the social media led representations of midsized bodies

Image by Emily Lucy Rajch

By Katy Leverett

Itâ€™s no new phenomena that the average woman has at least once felt underrepresented by the fashion industry. Be that runway models, magazine covers, or celebrity icons, the industry was built on a bias towards slim body types. And letâ€™s not even start on the lack of race, disability and gender representation. However, the past decade or so has seen the breakthrough of plus size fashion. With most high street brands carrying a plus size clothing range and plus size models making runway and media appearances, plus size fashion has become somewhat of an industry norm. Of course, this was the progression we were so longing for.

Yet despite meeting this consumer yearning for a wider sense of inclusivity, many of us still felt underrepresented. It sounds trivial and almost false; an average sized woman asking for more representation of her body type. But this is how so many women feel.

The â€˜plus sizeâ€™ category typically represents those that wear a UK size 18 equivalent or above. Any size below this is therefore assumed as one category; weâ€™re sometimes treated to the privilege of a â€˜petiteâ€™ or â€˜tallâ€™ range, but there is rarely any differentiation under this defaulted umbrella. However, there is a vast range of sizes and body types that fall below a size 18, just like there are for sizes that fall above. Women that wear a size 4 obviously donâ€™t resemble the same body type as those that buy a size 16, yet the closer we fall to the unexplained plus size threshold, the less representation we seem to receive.

Online shopping is a minefield of chaos and confusion â€“ most ventures of which usually end with an all too familiar trip to the post office. Yet, itâ€™s made even harder when the people that are modelling these clothes bear no resemblance to your own body type. There tends to be two types of models represented on online shopping outlets: those that are selling the standard size range or those that represent the â€˜plus sizeâ€™ category. Standard sized models almost always wear a UK size 8 or below and plus size models are mostly seen in a size 18; both sizes which sit at the lower end of their representative. As a result, those of us that sit in this unspoken limbo are left longing for relatability and representation.

As we all know, womenâ€™s sizing is more inconsistent than British weather

This is where the latest sub-culture of social media comes in: mid-size fashion. The term mid-size first popped up to me on one of my many nightly ritual TikTok scrolls and clicking on the hashtag led to me to an abundance of women whose bodies looked somewhat similar to mine. From what Iâ€™ve gathered, this emerging term denotes those that wear between a UK size 12-16 â€“ a range that I slot nicely into.

Across my short-lived years of womanhood, Iâ€™ve worn a vast range of sizes, fitting between a size 6 and 16 at different points in my life, and depending on the retailer. In my current wardrobe, you can find labels that read size S and size XL. As we all know, womenâ€™s sizing is more inconsistent than British weather.

Like many, Iâ€™ve faced extensive battles with body image and my mental health has had a massive effect on my weight. For the majority of my teenage and adult years, the number or letter inside my clothes was tightly correlated with myself-esteem. But with a lot of self-growth, help from the social media led body positivity movement, and a touch of therapy, I have just about come to accept this vessel that keeps me alive. Unfortunately though, this is not yet the case for many still battling with self-acceptance, yearning to see their body type beyond the mirror.

The average UK womenâ€™s size is actually a size 16, despite what clothing retailers and the media will lead you to believe. So, why is the average size considered a niche on social media; another social media sub section? However, the rawness of TikTok has allowed for this â€˜communityâ€™ to gain more recognition, with the hashtag â€˜midsizeâ€™ receiving over two billion views at the time of writing. And so, it seems that itâ€™s not just me that appreciates this representation. Despite their many flaws, platforms like TikTok and Instagram have been pivotal in pioneering body positivity movements. The ease at which creators can share content and viewers can receive it has catalysed the movement and allowed for a greater representation of womenâ€™s bodies that has been lacking in mainstream media for so long.
TikTok hauls of shoppers trying on their purchases and facing the exact same battles and triumphs that mirror my own experiences are a settling familiarity. The struggles of buying a size 10 in one shop and a size 16 in another no longer feel like an act of shame to me, something I for so long felt like I couldnâ€™t dare tell my friends for fear of judgement. Itâ€™s a refreshing reality that has been silenced by industry-fuelled toxicity for far too long. Not only is this subsection of social media settling to my mental health and body image struggles, the practical impacts are also pretty helpful; knowing which shops to size up or down in has saved me many changing room breakdowns and endless trips to my local Hermes drop off site.

Those of us that fall into the midsize category must not fall guilty to ignorance though. We still receive a lot of benefit from a lot of the fashion industryâ€™s privileged sizing. Unlike many of those that purchase plus-size clothing, mid-size consumers can still walk into most high street stores and leave with something that fits them; by no means may it be an easy and enjoyable trip, but nevertheless we still have this privilege. Yet, it still doesnâ€™t help heal the frustration and embarrassment felt walking into Zara and finding a size small, and if youâ€™re lucky a medium, are the biggest sizes available on the rails. However, a lot of mid-size bodies may also have the benefit of shopping between both standard and plus-size ranges, another privilege which is inaccessible to plus-size shoppers.

We need this social media space to make up for the lack of mainstream representation

The growth of the mid-size movement has also opened up many more conversations about sizing and body representation in the fashion industry. Many retailers that provide plus-size ranges, often donâ€™t use plus-size models to advertise their clothing, or employ models who are much slimmer than the average plus-sized person. For example, model Ashley Graham, is constantly praised by the media for being a â€˜plus-sized modelâ€™, yet Graham notably sits at the lower end of the plus-size range. These skewed representations of reality only negatively impact our own perceptions and body images. It creates an inevitable disappointment and low self-esteem when your size 14 dress doesnâ€™t look the same on your body as it did on the size 8 model. And similarly, for the size 22 woman whoâ€™s crying in front of the mirror because her jeans donâ€™t resemble the same fit they did on the size 16 model. Despite these retailers seemingly advocating for different body shapes, it is clear that the vast majority of bodies are simply not represented by the media and clothing retailers. And so hopping onto TikTok and finding an abundance of bodies that look just like mine is refreshing. We need this social media space to make up for the lack of mainstream representation. Finding outfit inspiration that is actually modelled on a body similar to my own is settling compared to the more commonly found Pinterest-adored slim outfit photos of social media.

This subsection of the internet may be considered a niche online, but to most consumers this is just normality. It is quite literally the average size.

Whilst mid-size influencers are still outnumbered compared to their slimmer counterparts, social media is definitely still the place to go for this representation. In fact, this â€˜movementâ€™ of mid-sized bodies was set up on Instagram by Anushka Moore who runs the page @midsizecollective; as her bio puts it, the page is â€œthe original home of not petite but not plus-sized styleâ€. The Instagram page shares photos of women of a range of body types and shapes; itâ€™s a gentle reminder that one label doesnâ€™t have to equate to the same body type, but instead captures a wide range of sizes. Another favourite Instagram account of mine is @midsize-millennial. Robynâ€™s content ranges between outfit photos and reels, sharing videos such as â€œwhat I ordered vs what it looks like on meâ€ and try on hauls. For major outfit inspiration, @oliviavcoxand @phoebemarthaevans are amongst some of my go to accounts.

For those of us that prefer the endless blackhole that is TikTok, @midsizefashioninspo creates raw and relatable content, with chatty try on hauls and outfit videos â€“ her videos feel like a familiar FaceTime call from your best friend. Similarly, @busybeecarys shares the realities of her journey with body image through outfit of the day videos and hauls. Of course, these are just a handful of the content creators that represent mid-sized bodies, but filling our feeds and For You Pages with body positive and representative content can do wonders for our own body image. Feeds full of carefully posed and edited images are often harmful to our perceptions of our own bodies, fuelling self-criticism and insecurities as we compare our bodies to those online. Thereâ€™s no shame in utilising the unfollow button if it means youâ€™re able to see yourself beyond the mirror.
